content.question: How does the rulerâ€™s feather headdress (probably of Motecuhzoma II) make an explicit statement about the power of the Mexica Empire?

choices.label: It symbolized the goddess Coyolxauhqui, indicating that the Mexica emperor was descended from the gods.
It featured glyphs on golden plaques that proclaimed the power of the Mexica over their conquered peoples.
It was made of rare materials, demonstrating the control of the Mexica over distant peoples and trade networks.
It included many feathers that represented royal ancestors, emphasizing the long lineage of the ruling imperial dynasty.

content.answer: It was made of rare materials, demonstrating the control of the Mexica over distant peoples and trade networks.
